Intervention: Ethiopian guidelines management of moderate and severe acute malnutrition
Effects and effect size: Duration of MAM with treatment; duration of MAM without treatment; duration of SAM with treatment; duration of SAM without treatment
Source: No studies directly report this due to ethical ground. We will generate estimates based on available evidence.

Intervention: Ready to use supplementary food (RUSF) for MAM
Effects and effect size: Reduction of severe wasting (RR: 0.74; 95% CI:0.57 to 0.95; 3 studies)

Severe stunting (RR 0·83, 95% CI 0·70–0·99, 4 studies); moderate stunting (RR 0·92, 0·84–1·00, 7 studies); moderate wasting (RR 0·83, 0·73–0·95, 8 studies); moderate underweight (RR 0·88, 0·80–0·96, 7 studies)
Source: Das et al. Cochrane Database Sys Rev 201910

Effects and effect size: Early initiation of breastfeeding (RR 1·20, 95% CI 1·12–1·28, 14 studies); Exclusive breastfeeding at 3 months (RR 2·02, 1·88–2·17, 6 studies); exclusive breastfeeding at 6 months (RR 1·53, 1·47–1·58, 19 studies, GRADE: very low); prevalence of diarrhea (RR 0·76, 0·67–0·85, 8 studies)

Exclusive breastfeeding at 6 to 12 months follow up: RR 3·03, 95% CI 2·31 to 3·97, four studies; mortality at latest follow up: RR 0·74, 95% CI 0·61 to 0·89, 14 studies; severe infection/sepsis at latest follow up: RR 0·85, 95% CI 0·79 to 0·92, nine studies;
Source: Conde-Agudelo et al Cochrane Database Sys Rev 201612 and Keats et al Lancet and Child Adolesc Health 20215

Effects and effect size: MD 11·5 h reduction in duration of diarrhea(95% CI 3·2–19·7); MD 15·8 h reduction in duration of persistent diarrhea (6·2–25·4); 57% increase (95% CI 32–86) in vomiting
Source: Lazzerini et al. Cochrane Database Sys Rev 201613

Effects and effect size: Incidence of diarrhea (RR 0·89, 95% CI 0·82–0·97, 11 studies); zinc deficiency (RR 0·37, 0·22–0·62, 11 studies); plasma serum zinc (MD 3·85, 2·48–5·23, 19 studies)

Plasma retinol concentration (MD 0·33 ?mol/L, 95% CI 0·01–0·65, 3 studies); Incidence of diarrhea (RR 0.85, 95% CI 0.82 to 0.87; 15 studies; 77,946 participants; low?quality evidence); measles (RR 0.50, 95% CI 0.37 to 0.67; 6 studies; 19,566 participants; moderate?quality evidence)
Source: Keats et al Lancet and Child Adolesc Health 20215; Imdad et al Cochrane Database Sys Rev 2017

Comparison group: Iron with or without folic acid
Effects and effect size: Fetal and newborn: Low birthweight (RR 0·85, 95% CI 0·77–0·93, 28 studies, GRADE: high); stillbirths† (RR 0·91, 0·86–0·98, 22 studies); SGA‡ (RR 0·93, 0·88–0·98, 19 studies); preterm births§ (RR 0·96, 0·91–1·01, 29 studies); Childhood: Executive function (SMD 0·09, 95% CI 0·01–0·17, 3 studies); diarrhea incidence (RR 0·84, 95% CI 0·76–0·92, 4 studies); retinol concentration (MD 0·06 ?mol/L, 95% CI 0·02–0·09, 3 studies)

Comparison group: No intervention or low energy supplement
Effects and effect size: 40% (95%CI: 14–59) reduction in low birthweight; 61% (95%CI: 20–81) reduction in risk of stillbirth; 29% reduction (95%CI6–46) in SGA

Intervention: Intermittent preventative treatment of malaria during pregnancy
Target population: Pregnant women in areas where there is malaria risk
Effects and effect size: increases mean birthweight by around 93 g (MD 92.72 g, 95% CI 62.05 to 123.39; nine trials, 3936 participants, moderate quality evidence), reduces low birthweight by around 27% (RR 0.73, 95% CI 0.61 to 0.87; eight trials, 3619 participants, moderate quality evidence)
Source: Denitsa Radeva-Petrova et al Cochrane Database Sys Rev 201417

Target population: Everyone in areas where there is malaria risk
Source: Gamble et al Cochrane Database Sys Rev 200918

Intervention: TBD: to be determined;*Baseline coverage of interventions will be obtained from DHS, MICs, GBD or LiST tool. If not found, then we will assume 0% baseline coverage.
